Revised by Dee Bowers to incorporate additional materials and comply with CBH description standards
Brooklyn Historical Society
Brooklyn League annual reports and publications
Brooklyn League
ARC.159
0.4 Linear Feet in one manuscript box
1902-1912 The Brooklyn League was founded in 1898. This collection includes annual reports and publications, measures 0.4 linear feet, and spans the dates 1902 to 1912. ARC.159 1 of 1
Conditions Governing Access
Open to researchers without restriction.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Source and date of acquisition for the majority of this collection are unknown. The 1902 annual report was the gift of Mr. John B. Creighton, League Secretary, 1908. The 1905 annual dinner program was part of BC accession 2016.0011.
Arrangement
The materials are arranged by type.
Historical note
The Brooklyn League was founded on January 24, 1898 with the mission "to bring together for common action all citizens of the borough of Brooklyn who are interested in its welfare; to co-operate with officials in promoting and forwarding local improvements and in securing efficient and economical administration; to watch the conduct of public business and the course of legislation, both state and municipal; to procure for members timely and accurate information regarding all matters of public concern affecting the borough or any part of it; to support effectively whatever makes for the best interests of the borough or of the city-at-large, and to oppose whatever is hostile thereto." (1)
Membership to the Brooklyn League was open to any registered voter or taxpayer residing in Brooklyn upon election by the League's Membership Committee, and the payment of annual membership dues. Members of the Brooklyn League served on committees concerned with various civic and social issues in Brooklyn, including Education, Gas and Electricity, Municipal Ordinances, Legislation, Assessment and Taxation, etc. The Brooklyn League's headquarters was located in the Temple Bar Building at 44 Court Street in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn.
Sources
Constitution, Officers, and Committees, 1902; Brooklyn League collection, ARC.159, Box 1, Folder 1; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
If digital surrogates exist, they should be used in place of the originals whenever possible.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn League collection, ARC.159, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.
Related Materials
Brooklyn clubs collection (ARC.172)
Fraternal organizations of Brooklyn collection (ARC.147)
Scope and Contents
The Brooklyn League annual reports and publications measure 0.4 linear feet and span the dates 1902 to 1912. The collection includes annual reports for the years 1902 and 1905 to 1910. These reports feature summaries of the League's activities and accomplishments for each year, committee rosters, membership lists, and summaries of the League's financial standing for each year. The collection also includes correspondence between Mr. John B. Creighton, League secretary, and Long Island Historical Society Assistant Librarian Helen A. Morrison regarding the library's holdings of the League's annual reports.
Also included are a copy of the Brooklyn League's constitution, dated 1902, and printed pamphlets listing officers, committees and affiliated bodies, dated 1910 to 1912, as well as a 1905 program for the League's annual dinner which is an album of black and white photo postcard views of Brooklyn.
Conditions Governing Use
While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
